SafetyInspectionBy: State of Florida, Division of Emergency Management

_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: All Other Basic Organic Chemical Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
INTRODUCTION

SiVance LLC (SiVance) is a producer of specialty chemical products located in Gainesville, Florida. Integral to the manufacture of these products are three toxic chemicals (anhydrous ammonia, phosphorus oxychloride and trimethylchlorosilane) and four flammable chemicals (acetylene, dichlorosilane, pentane and trichlorosilane).  SiVance inventory may exceed the USEPA listed thresholds under the Risk Management Plan (RMP), codified at 40 CFR 68, for the above referenced materials. SiVance has implemented an RMP program.  SiVance has an outstanding record in environmental, health and safety performance.  The following sections outline the SiVance RMP program.



OVERALL RESPONSIBILITY

The SiVance Site Manager has overall responsibility for the RMP program at the facility with the assistance of the Environmental Safety and Health (ESH) Manager.  They share the overall responsibility for ensuring that the facility operates in a safe and reliable manner.  A primary responsibility includes overseeing the implementation of the RMP program.  To ensure the RMP is appropriately developed and implemented, SiVance's ownership has assigned the duties of RMP Coordinator to the Site Manager, an individual who has the necessary background, training, and experience for that duty.  The RMP Coordinator, acting with proper authority, has the responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the USEPA RMP elements.  In addition, the RMP Coordinator works closely with appropriate staff to integrate the appropriate elements of the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) program as required by Section 68.15 of the RMP rule.



The following sections identify the specific responsibilities for various aspects of the RMP and PSM programs.



HAZARD ASSESSMENT

The ESH Manager has the responsibility for (1) ensuring the off-site consequence analysis for the regulated processes are consistently performed and documented in accordance with Sections 68.20 through 68

.39 and (2) selecting the scenarios that will be reported in the facility RMP as required by Facility Ownership based on the recommendations of the RMP Coordinator.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The ESH Manager is responsible for ensuring that the accident history for the covered processes is appropriately documented and maintained in accordance with Sections 68.42 and 68.168 of the RMP rule.  SiVance has had no reportable release of any of the RMP regulated substances since 2001.



PREVENTION PROGRAM

The RMP Coordinator and those staff members assigned PSM responsibility, have the responsibility of ensuring that the facility has an integrated, effective, and compliant prevention program that meets or exceeds Section 68.65 through 68.87 of the RMP rule and OSHA PSM requirements.  The Site Manager ensures that staff delegated RMP and PSM responsibilities for all program elements are assigned and maintained.



PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION

The RMP Coordinator has the responsibility for process safety information, Section 68.65 of the RMP rule.  Process chemical information, process equipment information and process technology information are readily accessible for use.



PROCESS HAZARDS ANALYSIS

In accordance with RMP Section 68.57, the RMP Coordinator has the responsibility for scheduling, conducting, and documenting that the PHAs were completed by trained personnel for the covered processes.  The RMP Coordinator has delegated this responsibility to the ESH Manager (and prior to June 2019 to the Process Safety Manager) who designates appropriately trained personnel from within the facility to participate in the PHAs. The RMP Coordinator may select outside contractors to lead the PHAs.



OPERATING PROCEDURES

In accordance with RMP Section 68.71, the Site Manager must ensure that complete and accurate operating procedures are in place for the regulated processes. The Site Manager works with the ESH Manager to develop and maintain the facility's safe work practice

s.



TRAINING

In accordance with RMP Section 68.73, the ESH Manager has the responsibility for (1) ensuring that operations employees receive and understand training applicable to their specific jobs and associated processes and (2) documenting said training.  The ESH Manager and the Site Manager share the responsibility for (1) ensuring that all employees receive and understand training in safe work practices applicable to their jobs and (2) documenting said training.



MECHANICAL INTEGRITY

In accordance with RMP Section 68.73, the Engineering Services Manager has responsibility for the overall mechanical integrity program, with specific emphasis on written procedures, maintenance training, the equipment and instrumentation inspection/testing program and documentation, and equipment deficiency resolution.  SiVance employs contractors and/or consultants to assist in the implementation and maintenance of the mechanical integrity program.  The Engineering Services Manager works with appropriate maintenance personnel to define and maintain quality assurance procedures for equipment acquisitions/installation/repairs.



MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE

In accordance with RMP Section 68.75, the ESH Manager has responsibility for the management of change (MOC) program; however, the facility engineering staff and operations management have responsibility for ensuring that the overall MOC program is effectively implemented.



PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW

In accordance with RMP Section 68.77, the ESH Manager has responsibility for the overall pre-startup safety review program, which is closely tied to the MOC program.  However, the Site Manager and the ESH Manager have the combined responsibility for ensuring that this program is effectively implemented before affected operations begin.



COMPLIANCE AUDITS

In accordance with RMP Section 68.79, the ESH Manager has responsibility for ensuring that compliance audits are completed regularly with proper documentation to verify that the

prevention program is functioning properly and meets EPA/OSHA requirements.  Each staff member has responsibility for resolving any deficiencies noted in his/her area.



INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

In accordance with RMP Section 68.81, the ESH Manager has the responsibility of designing and managing the incident investigation program, including tracking resolution of investigation findings and recommendations.  The Site Manager has the responsibility of ensuring only trained personnel lead investigations. The ESH and Operations Managers share the responsibility for ensuring all incidents are reported and investigated in a timely manner, and that investigation findings are resolved, documented and communicated to affected personnel.



EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

In accordance with RMP Section 68.83, working with employee representatives on the various safety committees, the Site Manager is required to involve employees in the planning and implementation of the facility's prevention program elements.  



HOT WORK PERMITS

In accordance with RMP Section68.85, the ESH Manager with support from the Engineering Services Manager has responsibility for developing and maintaining the facility's hot work permit program.



CONTRACTORS

In accordance with RMP Section 68.87, the Engineering Services Manager has overall responsibility for the contractor program; however, the ESH Manager has responsibility for ensuring that the requirements of the program are implemented in his/her area of responsibility.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

In accordance with RMP Sections 68.90 and 68.95, the Site Manager is responsible for (1) designing, implementing, and maintaining the facility's emergency response plan; (2) ensuring that all associated training is conducted and documented as necessary; (3) coordinating the site emergency response plan with the appropriate community response plan and (4) responding to local emergency response planners/responders when questions arise.  Trained SiVance e

mployees may make an initial response in the event of an emergency release.  Personnel are trained to immediately notify appropriate facility managers. In such a situation, SiVance employees may be called upon to provide details on the process, equipment locations, and/or other facility-specific details that may be integral to emergency response activities.



RMP PLAN PREPARATION AND SUBMISSION

The Site Manager is responsible for preparing and submitting the RMP Plan for the facility as required as RMP Sections 68.150 through 68.185.



RMP PLAN COMMUNICATION

The Site Manager has the responsibility of providing RMP Plan information (other than the required USEPA submission) to employees and the public as required by RMP Section 68.210. SiVance has been an active participant in community outreach efforts to communicate the details and implications of its RMP to the members of potentially affected public.
